item.title: 1.1 Creating a New Project
item.description: Infrastructure in Pulumi is organized into projects. Each project is a single program that, when run, declares the desired infrastructure for Pulumi to manage. Step 1 — Create a Directory Each Pulumi project lives in its own directory. Create one now and change into it: mkdir iac-workshop cd iac-workshop Pulumi will use the directory name as your project name by default. You can change this during the project initiation process, but we’ll stick with the default for now.

item.title: 1.2 Configuring AWS
item.description: Now that we have a basic project, let’s add the Pulumi AWS provider and configure our credentials. Step 1 — Install the AWS Provider Run the following command: npm i @pulumi/aws This will install the Pulumi AWS node SDK and add it to your package.json file. This is the library that will allow us to manage AWS assets with Pulumi. Pulumi also supports a wide range of other providers. For a complete list of all supported providers, see the Pulumi Registry.

item.title: 1.3 Provisioning Infrastructure
item.description: Now that we have a project configured to use AWS, we can create some basic infrastructure. We will start with a simple S3 bucket. Step 1 — Declare a New Bucket Add the following to your index.ts file: const bucket = new aws.s3.Bucket("my-website-bucket", { website: { indexDocument: "index.html", }, }); After this change, your index.ts should look like this: import * as pulumi from "@pulumi/pulumi"; import * as aws from "@pulumi/aws"; const bucket = new aws.

item.title: 1.4 Updating Infrastructure
item.description: We just saw how to create new infrastructure. Next, let’s make a few updates.
